div.head: A LEAF NOT FROM THE "BOOKS OF THE OPERA"
div.p: You might as well set me down for a heathen, for I don't like the opera, and what is more, I don't believe half the people who say that they do, else why do they laugh and whisper through the perfomance, and twist their moustaches into horny shapes, and settle their bracelets, and arrange their shawls and make eyes, and do anything but what they profess to come there for—viz., to listen to the music. It is all a sham; they go there because it is a good place to show off—because there are handsome men and pretty women there—because it is the fashion. Shall I like a thing merely because 'tis the fashion? Shall I sit in a vapor bath in one torturing posture from seven o'clock till twelve, at the mercy of the cramp, for fashion? It is all very well for gentlemen who run out between the acts, and come in wiping their satisfied lips so provokingly, to ask, "Why not stand up in these intervals?" It is not so agreeable to have a dozen impertinent lorgnettes leveled at you, to hear your name handed from mouth to mouth, and your genealogy, from Adam down, discussed in your hearing by your well-bred neighbors. Some people diligently study the "book of the opera" to find out what all the deafening racket is about. I never touch one. If the music is good for anything, I take it, it will tell its own story, and if it is not, it is bad enough to be forced to listen to it, without boring yourself to read what it is intended to do. I have been to the opera when the music appealed to me; when my heart stood still, lest I should lose a note; when I was dying to throw my arms round somebody's neck—(not anybody's) and cry for sheer ecstacy. That's what I call music; but that's only a delicious parenthesis I occasionally get there at the cost of a seven hours' sit. But a slam-bang crash, an ear-splitting squeal; eyes turned inside out; mouth twisted under the ears; fat, red-faced prima-donnas trying to get out of their gowns at the top I will none of it, especially when it takes till day-light to get from Fourteenth street back to my pillow in Brooklyn.

Spite of that, I maintain that I love music. I can't sing a note—more's the pity. I can't prate about "Verdi," and "Rossini" and "Bellini," and all the other ninnys, but I like a baby's laugh; I like a brook's ripple; I like the shivering leaf-music in the tall tree-tops in the woods; I like the spirit-voices in the starry midnight; but I don't want my ears deafened, and my eyes put out, and my enthusiasm bottled up to be uncorked to the order of the Acadamy of Music in Fourteenth street, whether or no. In short, I don't like the opera one time in ten. There—now you have it.
